Description: Upper half of a hollow-cast figure of Mahes (or Mihos), son of Bastet in copper alloy; the lion-headed male deity holds the sickle sword khepesh in his right hand against his chest; broken below chest and left arm missing; small almost rectangular hole (0.6 x 0.4 cm) on the top of the head, most likely for element of crown; though incomplete, metal fairly well preserved.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), House of 'cache of bronzes'
Curator's comments: This figure was found with a large group of copper alloy finds in a house on the south of the town (Petrie 1886, 41-42). It corresponds to the ‘upper part of a large figure of Bast’ listed by Petrie. The cache was probably made around the late 5th-early 4th c. BC, but some bronzes from this cache could be earlier in date (Masson 2015). This figure belongs to the type 106 in the typology of figure bronzes by K. Weiss (Weiss 2012, 201-202, 666-669, Taf. 29 a-d, Taf. 73, Typ 106). Bronze figures of Mahes were mainly discovered in Leontopolis and Bubastis where his cult as the son of Bastet was the most dynamic. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Masson, A. 2015, ‘Cult and Trade. A reflexion on Egyptian metal offerings from Naukratis’, in D. Robinson and F. Goddio (eds), Thonis Heracleion in Context, Oxford Centre for Maritime Archaeology Monograph 8, Oxford, 71-88. Weiss, K. 2012, Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten : Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland, Ägypten und Altes Testament 81.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (MB.175) (phase 3)
Masson 2015 / Cult and Trade A reflexion on Egyptian metal offerings from Naukratis (76, fig. 3.7)
